"Having considered your arguments the Commissioner will conduct an investigation into the DWP’s response of 19 February 2015. The scope of the case will be to determine on the balance of probabilities whether any further information is held to item 1.3 of your request of 31 July 2014:

1. <example bulk ad-reposter>

A substantial number of adverts currently featured on Universal Jobmatch are from the advertiser <example bulk ad-reposter> (for example, Job ID: 9218799, reference code: 170679).

3. In a spreadsheet (ODF or CSV format):
(a). Summary of adverts posted per day
(b). Content of posted adverts"

Any IT folks care to bet on that data not being in the database? For a system they licensed from a very well-known recruitment site?

The Wikipedia Signpost has decided to take a few more 'pot-shots' at Wikinews. As one of Wikinews' main contributors, who was asked to write a piece - at short notice, with no knowledge of the attack planned against the project - I am mildly amused.

Ergo, The Signpost supports Wikinews, or they've a lot to learn about journalism.

Over the past few days, several articles have contained exclusive content - on-the-scene reports from international sport, exclusive interviews with contenders for the US presidential election, and even an article based on reports from our contact in Homs, Syria.

So it's pleasing to check Facebook's stats and be told that these have come alongside a surge in readers. Looks like word is really getting around about Wikinews.

Don't forget, if anything you see interests you, please do share it - we've got our sights set on over 9,000 likes here by the end of the year. This isn't just a matter of pride, although we're certainly proud of what we do; this is also about trying to provide a decent alternative news source, which is something we think everyone deserves.

A big thank you to everyone who's reading our stuff, especially to those spreading the word. We mean it.

It's great to see Wikinews increasing in popularity, and reaching more people. Since the challenge was set at the turn of the year to reach "over nine thousand" likes, we've garnered around 2,000 new likes.

The reach of our content is now such that over 30,000 people each week see something from Wikinews.

Thank you to those who read our work, and to those who share it with their friends. That 9,000 is looking achievable.

Wikinews truely is the news written by people like you for people like you. In fact, if you're feeling up for a challenge, why not come over and have a go at writing your own neutral report and getting it past our fact-checking system? Then you too can be a part of high-quality news coverage!

Following the direct posting yesterday of a Russia Today opinion piece on ACTA to Wikinews' wall — accompanied by a 'call to arms', our "Info" page has been updated with a polite reminder not to abuse the open posting policy in-place here.

We'd be delighted were we able to direct people to our "request an article" page; but, first we could do with recruiting more contributors able to rise to the challenging standards Wikinews sets — and able to do so in the face of ever-present deadlines.

That does not rule out following up to a Wikinews article with a link to another news source's related coverage; such a response is readily identified as your own, and not Wikinews endorsing someone else's editorial stance.

Just promoted to Featured status, this December story on the conclusion of the trial prompted by the 2005 Helios flight 522 crash, joins the select few articles considered the "best of Wikinews".

As pointed out during the article's candidacy, where it may not be as long as many recently promoted, it was largely the most comprehensive English-language coverage of the two-year court proceedings.

Topics covered include the IMF's managing director's call for action on the Eurozone crisis, a war crimes court charging four over violence in Kenya, a war of words as Arab League observers leave Syria, and Salman Rushdie facing censorship anew in India.

We invite you to join us in a town hall on Oct 26th to discuss what real police reform looks like. The recent Department of Justice report on the Baltimore City Police Department exposed the rampant abuse many in Baltimore know well, but many think it fell short of offering real solutions to end this abuse through accountability. 

What does real community control of the police look like? Why are officers so infrequently jailed, or even fired, for abuse? Can you reform the police department from within? How do you deal with police reform without dealing with chronic poverty, low wages, and the war on drugs?

Activists, elected officials and candidates, scholars, police officers and other Baltimore residents will discuss and debate how to affect real change. We'll look into what the DOJ and other government bodies can do, and what communities can do right now. We'll also examine the role of police in society, and what we want that role to be.

Let's come up with real solutions to make the police department accountable to the people of Baltimore, and respect people's constitutional rights.
